author.literal: C++ Beginning C++ ➤ Harvey M. Deitel and Paul J. Deitel, C++ How to Program

note: Introduction to Standard C++ (Second Edition), Prentice Hall, 2000, ISBN: 0-139-79809-9. An excellent introduction to C++ programming that expects the reader to know C already. Available at no cost online at www.bruceeckel.com. ➤ Stanley B. Lippman, Josée Lajoie, and Barbara E. Moo, C++ Primer (Fourth Edition), Addison-Wesley, 2005, ISBN: 0-201-72148-1. Requires no knowledge of C++, but assumes experience with high-level objectoriented languages.
title: This appendix contains a list of books and online resources on various C++-related topics that were either consulted while writing this book, or are recommended for further or background reading
ISBN: 0-136-11726-0. Known as the “Deitel” book, this text assumes no prior programming experience. ➤ Bruce Eckel, Thinking in C++

note: Second Edition), O’Reilly, 2003, ISBN: 0-596-00419-2. An introductory C++ text that assumes no prior programming experience.

title: Problem Solving with C++
This book assumes no prior programming experience. It is often used as a textbook in introductory programming courses

author.literal: General C++ ➤ Marshall Cline, C++ FAQ LITE, www.parashift.com/c++-faq-lite. ➤ Marshall Cline, Greg Lomow, and Mike Girou, C++ FAQs (Second Edition), Addison-Wesley

note: The printed version contains more information than the online version, but the material available online should be sufficient for most professional C++ programmers.
title: ISBN: 0-201-30983-1. This compilation of frequently asked questions from the comp.lang.c++ newsgroup is useful for quickly looking up a specific point about C++

note: Provides 99 specific tips for C++ programming.
The second volume of Eckel’s book covers more advanced C++ topics. It’s also available at no cost online at www.bruceeckel.com.

title: ISBN: 0-596-00298-X. A C++ reference covering everything from the basics to more-advanced material
Effective C++
55 Specific Ways to Improve Your Programs and Designs

note: These two books provide excellent tips and tricks on commonly misused and misunderstood features of C++.
title: More Effective C++: 35 New Ways to Improve Your Programs and Designs

note: One of the most comprehensive C++ books available.

title: The C++ Programming Language (Special Third Edition
ISBN: 0-201-70073-5. The “Bible” of C++ books, written by the designer of C++ himself. Every C++ programmer should own a copy of this book, but it can be a bit obscure in places for the C++ novice

author.literal: I/O Streams and Strings ➤ Cameron Hughes and Tracey Hughes, Mastering the Standard C++ Classes: An Essential Reference, Wiley

container-title: ➤ Joel Spolsky, The Absolute Minimum Every Software Developer Absolutely, Positively Must Know About Unicode and Character Sets
note: No Excuses!), www.joelonsoftware.com/ articles/Unicode.html. After reading Joel’s treatise on the importance of localization, you’ll want to check out his other entries on Joel on Software.
publisher: Practical Techniques for Building Better Software, Addison-Wesley
title: ISBN: 0-471-32893-6. A good book for learning how to write custom istream and ostream classes. ➤ Cameron Hughes and Tracey Hughes, Stream Manipulators and Iterators in C++, www.informit.com/articles/article.aspx?p=171014. This well-written article by the authors of Mastering the Standard C++ Classes takes the mystery out of defi ning custom stream manipulators in C++. ➤ Philip Romanik and Amy Muntz
ISBN: 0-321-10894-9. In addition to a unique blend of software development advice and C++ specifics, this book provides one of the best explanations we’ve read of locale and Unicode support in C++
➤ The Unicode Consortium, The Unicode Standard 5.0
ISBN: 0-321-48091-0. This is the defi nitive book on Unicode, which all developers using Unicode must have

note: An explanation of what the Universal Character Set (UCS) is, including the Unicode standard.
title: Where is my Character?, www.unicode.org/standard/where. The best resource for fi nding Unicode characters, charts, and tables. ➤ Wikipedia Universal Character Set, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ Universal_Character_Set

author.literal: The C++ Standard Library ➤ Nicolai M. Josuttis

title: The C++ Standard Library: A Tutorial and Reference
ISBN: 0-201-37926-0. This book covers the entire standard library, including I/O streams and strings as well as the containers and algorithms. It’s an excellent reference

note: books. It provides targeted tips for using the STL, but is not a reference or tutorial.
title: 50 Specific Ways to Improve Your Use of the Standard Template Library
ISBN: 0-201-74962-9. Meyers wrote this book in the same spirit as his “Effective C++

note: This book is similar to the Josuttis text, but covers only the STL part of the standard library.
title: STL Tutorial and Reference Guide

note: This book explains the new features added to the C++ Standard Library with the Technical Report 1 (TR1).
title: The C++ Standard Library Extensions: A Tutorial and Reference

note: Shows/Going+Deep/ C9-Lectures-Introduction-to-STL-with-Stephan-T-Lavavej. An interesting video lecture series on the C++ Standard Template Library. C++ Templates

Everything you ever wanted to know (or didn’t want to know) about C++ templates. It assumes significant background in general C++. ➤ David Abrahams and Aleksey Gurtovoy, C++ Template Metaprogramming: Concepts,
title: Sutter’s Mill: Befriending Templates
The best explanation we could fi nd about making function templates friends of classes
Tools, and Techniques from Boost and Beyond
This book delivers practical metaprogramming tools and techniques into the hands of the everyday programmer

A description of all new features added to C++11. ➤ ECMAScript Language Specification, www.ecma-international.org/publications/ files/ECMA-ST/ECMA-262.pdf. The syntax of the regular expressions in C++11 is the same as the regular expressions in the ECMAScript language, described in this specification document
The C Programming Language
ISBN: 0-131-10362-8. “K&R,” as this book is known, is a reference on the C language, but it’s not so useful for learning it the fi rst time

note: Every C programmer should own a copy.
title: C: A Reference Manual, Fifth Edition
ISBN: 0-130-89592-X. This book can be considered a replacement for the K&R book. Instead of a narrative style, where knowledge is embedded in the text, it is done as a more formal reference manual
ISBN: 0-596-00436-2. A concise reference to all things C
The Art and Science of C: A Library Based Introduction to Computer Science

note: They are often used as textbooks in introductory programming courses.
title: Programming Abstractions in C: A Second Course in Computer Science
ISBN: 0-201-54541-1. These two books provide a great introduction to programming in C with good style
ISBN: 0-131-77429-8. An enlightening and often hysterical look at the C language, its evolution, and its inner workings
ISBN: 0-596-00701-9. This book provides step-by-step instructions for using JNI to integrate Java with other languages, including C++

author.literal: ALGORITHMS AND DATA STRUCTURES ➤ Thomas H. Cormen, Charles E. Leiserson, Ronald L. Rivest, and Clifford Stein

note: Seminumerical Algorithms (Third Edition), Addison-Wesley, 1997, ISBN: 0-201-89684-2. ➤ Donald E. Knuth, The Art of Computer Programming Volume 3: Sorting and Searching (Second Edition), Addison-Wesley, 1998, ISBN: 0-201-89685-0. ➤ Donald E. Knuth, The Art of Computer Programming Volume 4A:

For those of you who enjoy mathematical rigor, there is no better algorithms and data structures text than Knuth’s four-volume tome. But, it is probably inaccessible without undergraduate knowledge of mathematics or theoretical computer science.
title: Introduction to Algorithms
ISBN: 0-262-03384-4. This text is one of the most popular introductory algorithms books, covering all the common data structures and algorithms
The Art of Computer Programming Volume 1: Fundamental Algorithms
The Art of Computer Programming
ISBN: 1-565-92453-3. An approachable reference to data structures and algorithms

author.literal: RANDOM NUMBERS ➤ Eric Bach and Jeffrey Shallit, Algorithmic Number Theory

container-title: OPEN-SOURCE SOFTWARE ➤ The Open Source Initiative at www.opensource.org. ➤ The GNU Operating System — Free Software Foundation at www.gnu.org. These web pages for the two main open-source movements explain their philosophies and provide information about obtaining open-source software and contributing to its development. Software Engineering Methodology ❘ 1041
title: ➤ Oded Goldreich, Modern Cryptography, Probalistic Proofs and Pseudorandomness

ISBN: 3-642-08432-X. Both of these books explain the theory of computational pseudo randomness. ➤ Wikipedia Mersenne Twister, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mersenne_twister. A mathematical explanation of the Mersenne Twister to generate pseudo-random numbers

author.literal: SOFTWARE ENGINEERING METHODOLOGY ➤ Barry W. Boehm

title: TRW Defense Systems Group, A Spiral Model of Software Development and Enhancement
This landmark paper described the state of software development at the time and proposed the Spiral Model
Extreme Programming Explained: Embrace Change
ISBN: 0-321-27865-8. One of several books in a series that promote Extreme Programming as a new approach to software development
Quality Software Project Management
ISBN: 0-130-91297-2. A guidebook for anybody who is responsible for the management of software development processes
Facts and Fallacies of Software Engineering
ISBN: 0-321-11742-5. This book discusses various aspects of the software development process and exposes hidden truisms along the way
The Rational Unifi ed Process: An Introduction
Provides an overview of RUP, including its mission and processes
ISBN: 0-131-43635-X. A wonderfully enlightening book about the politics and realities of software development
➤ Rational Unified Process from IBM

author.literal: PROGRAMMING STYLE ➤ Martin Fowler, Kent Beck, John Brant, William Opdyke, and Don Roberts

title: Refactoring: Improving the Design of Existing Code
ISBN: 0-201-48567-2. This classic book espouses the practice of recognizing and improving bad code

container-title: Exhibits the tenets of Microsoft Windows coding style, using Visual Basic .NET
title: Practical Standards for Microsoft Visual Basic .NET
➤ Diomidis Spinellis, Code Reading: The Open Source Perspective
ISBN: 0-201-79940-5. This unique book turns the issue of programming style upside down by challenging the reader to learn to read code properly in order to become a better programmer

note: reading, modifying, testing, debugging, and writing.
title: A highly configurable program that generates documentation from source code and comments
A nice little book with advice about how to perform the most common operations on code
A discussion on what code refactoring means, including a number of techniques for refactoring
Computer Organization and Design: The Hardware/ Software Interface
Computer Architecture: A Quantitative Approach
ISBN: 0-123-70490-1. These two books provide all the information most software engineers ever need to know about computer architecture
Effective Software Testing: 50 Specific Ways to Improve Your Testing
ISBN: 0-201-79429-2. While this book is aimed at quality assurance professionals, any software engineer will benefit from its discussion of the software-testing process

note: You could spend all day browsing through this community-edited website about design patterns.
title: Modern C++ Design: Generic Programming and Design Patterns Applied

ISBN: 0-201-70431-5. Offers an approach to C++ programming employing highly reusable code and patterns. ➤ Cunningham and Cunningham, The Portland Pattern Repository, www.c2.com/cgi/ wiki?WelcomeVisitors

note: Called the “Gang of Four” book (because of its four authors), this text is the seminal work on design patterns.
title: Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software
➤ Wikipedia Design Patterns, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Design_pattern_ (computer_science). Contains a description of a large number of design patterns used in computer programming
Operating System Concepts (Eighth Edition
ISBN: 0-470-12872-0. A great discussion on operating systems, including multithreading issues such as deadlocks and race conditions
